Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Hans gave this a quick test, and I've tested the boot-loaded ppt_aliases/matches seem to work as intended. This is enough to hack a zonecfg to use a .../devices/ path. No vmadm support yet.

Josh, is the JSON output reasonable to you?

I'll also deliver a standard /etc/ppt_matches file with our GPGPU PCI IDs.

Change has been successfully merged by John Levon
I don't believe we should be shipping these compilation symlinks. See comment on the ips manifest.
OK
I don't believe we should be shipping these compilation symlinks. See comment on the ips manifest.
OK
Worth doing a ctfconvert on this?
OK
Should we just replace this with calls to errx(3C)?
We can't replace due to the first argument, but can certainly use verrx().
Seems like this could be replaced with calls to warn[x](3C).
But this can go, thanks.
Any reason we don't check the return value?
Well, it's a "can't happen", libppt would have broken its contract with us. Although I will initialize val at least so we don't get *random* behaviour.
OK, fair enough.
Do we care about reporting truncation?
libofmt uses a 1024-byte buffer.  I don't think other consumers worry about this, and nor should we?
OK. I'm not other consumers are right or not. If I was relying on parseable output and it was truncated, seems like I'd be annoyed. That said, it's unlikely to happen here, so it's probably fine.
It'd be nice if the calls to usage() could say what was wrong for the user. As in these options cannot be used together, extraneous options, etc.
Sure.
Out of curiosity is there a reason that we want it to be one giant JSON blob versus new-line separated JSON, etc.?
The JSON output is entirely for non-human consumption. It didn't seem worth adding new interfaces to the libnvpair JSON code?

This was less of a concern for humans or not versus having to buffer it all in memory. But I think this ultimately is the same as the libppt question I asked about interfaces and we concluded that it won't be large enough to worry about for now.
Shouldn't we actually check the output value of printf here when we're considering how to exit? If we hit ENOSPC, EIO, etc. it's not clear that we should exit 0, for example.
I suppose? I'm not sure I've come across any of the *adm utils that take care of this in their parsable output before.

The main reason I was thinking about it was if this wasn't JSON, how would the consumer actually know it got everything versus hit an error? I guess in this case we'll get corrupted JSON which won't parse.
Missing dep on libnvpair?
Not needed as per line 587
style nit: Split this comment after the license text.
OK
style nit: 'get_int_prop' seems a little misleading since it's adding a value to the nvlist too.  Perhaps something like 'populate_int_prop'?
Agreed.
Do we want to include the subsystem name at all here?

As the only use I know of for the label right now is essentially just for convenience for a dev/test/operator running pptadm on a CN, I don't think it's worth it. That is, I don't know of any need to push up this human-readable identification anywhere else than pptadm. Can add, though, if you think it's worth-while.
That seems reasonable. If we want it elsewhere, we can always use the pci db there.
nit: cache this on a const var or something?
done
Is there a reason we don't keep track of an errpath so we can indicate that to the caller.

It seems like a pretty unlikely case to be worth reporting up, especially given how much it would complicate the interface to have an errfunc, and it's not clear to me that the path would really help in debugging a failure here (I'd still need to go look at /dev/ afterwards to see what happened I think). But if you feel strongly I can add an error callback.

I wasn't trying to suggest that the caller should pass errfunc into the library, apologies that this was unclear. I wasn't certain if glob would return non-zero if encountered those errors or not. On my initial reading of the manual page, it seemed like it would drive on and we wouldn't know we missed anything.
If we bailed between L188-L198, this will not have been zeroed yet and will probably blow up.
Oops.
style nit: Could just initialize 'err' to 0 when it is declared
Sure (though in general, I'm not a big fan of this style, as it always runs the risk of err getting set to non-zero during the success path e.g. looking up something that only optionally exists).
shouldn't this set data->nd_err?
Yep

Is this process bother than using the di_devlink_* family of functions? I'm not sure which path would end up being more expensive. Though I guess if we were worried about the cost, we could probably cache the devlink and devinfo information in a library handle.
I'm not following what using di_devlink_* brings us here, beyond a bunch of pain.

The only reason I thought about it originally was that here we have to do all the work to get the full ppt_list_assigned(), find a match, and then throw it out. It wasn't clear to me if the di_devlink_* family of functions which basically reports the minor node to /dev mapping would be simpler and/or faster than building the nvlist. It may be both slower and more complicated. Just thought it was worth mentioning. It may not be worth implementing.

Is there value in making this a streaming interface with callbacks rather than translating it all into one giant nvlist? I guess the set of devices here will be small since we're limited by the number of PCI slots on the system and the onboard devices?

If this were ZFS for example, trying to populate a single nvlist of say file systems would lead to trouble.
Right, it seems unlikely this would ever be a ZFS-like size. If it were, it would be simple enough to change, but right now it would just mean more code.
Should probably mention that -o is required for the -p option.
done

Why are we shipping compilation symlinks and lint libraries, but not the header. Seems like it should be all or nothing and in this case, really, none of them because this is intended to be a private interface.
Done
We'll leak 'pm' in this case, since it's not being added to the list.
style nit: Could pre-initialize 'err' to ENOENT and skip the goto/label
Any reason not to make this a top-level variable like dafile?
Is there a particular reason you chose '-?' instead of the more common '-h' for this? This would be really awkward to type in a shell as it is a wildcard character and requires escaping.

-? has long been the Solarish standard, used in e.g. zoneadm, coreadm, rctladm, etc. See
 https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E26505_01/html/816-5165/intro-1.html

"--help (with the short-option synonym -?"

It also seems pretty unlikely that people have "-o" files around etc.

Having said that, I don't care much for -? myself, so if you prefer -h it's fine by me. There's at least some precedent there too.
Interesting, I didn't know that. Perhaps you could add '-h' as a synonym to '-?'?
